title: 111_hr6309
content: The Act is titled the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010". Definitions are provided in Section 2. In this Act, a "business entity" is defined as any organization established for profit through commerce in the United States. "Commerce" is defined as in the Consumer Product Safety Act, and a "consumer" is an individual within the U.S. jurisdiction. The term "consumer" refers to an individual in the U.S. who buys goods or services for personal use. "Customer service communication" is any communication between a consumer and a business for commerce. Service communication refers to telecommunication or wire communication between a consumer and a business entity in furtherance of commerce. Telecommunication involves the transmission of chosen information without alteration, while wire communication includes the transmission of various forms of data. The term "communication by wire" refers to the transmission of various forms of data using wire, cable, or similar connections between points of origin and reception, including all services related to such transmission. Required disclosure by business entities engaged in customer service communications of physical location. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, unless all employees or agents are located in the United States. Employees or agents of a business entity participating in customer service communication are exempt from disclosing their physical location if the communication was initiated by the consumer and the employee or agent is located outside the United States. Employees or agents located outside the United States are exempt from disclosing their physical location in customer service communication initiated by the consumer. Emergency services are also excluded from these disclosure requirements. The Federal Trade Commission has the authority to exclude certain business entities from these regulations. The Federal Trade Commission can exclude certain business entities or customer service communications from disclosure requirements if exceptionally compelling circumstances justify it. Each year, participating business entities must certify compliance with these requirements. The FTC must establish regulations within one year of the Act's enactment. The Federal Trade Commission must establish regulations within one year of the Act's enactment to carry out the provisions related to customer service communications. The requirements of subsection (a) will apply to communications occurring one year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The Federal Trade Commission has the power to prevent violations of the Act and its regulations, treating non-compliance as a violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive practices. The Act incorporates terms and provisions of the Federal Trade Commission Act, including penalties for violations. The Act preserves the authority of the Federal Trade Commission. The Act incorporates terms and provisions of the Federal Trade Commission Act, including penalties for violations, and preserves the authority of the Federal Trade Commission under any other provision of law.
